title: 106_hr4730
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, recognized by Congress, are descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation. They are also successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington, with over 2,500 eligible members residing in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the Creek Indian Nation, chose to stay near their ancestral homeland in Georgia. They operate as a sovereign tribe with a tribal government and petitioned for Federal recognition in 1972. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia petitioned for Federal recognition in 1972 but lacked proper legal counsel and historical information, leading to a denial in 1981. Despite this, they have been recognized by the Federal Government, the State of Georgia, and local governments as a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia or an individual placed on the membership rolls according to this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Tribe, making them eligible for all Federal benefits and services available to federally recognized Indian tribes. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RESERVATION. The Tribe can transfer land to the Secretary for trust within 2 years, establishing it as the initial reservation land with a prohibition on gaming. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution and Bill of Rights. The Secretary will publish notice in the Federal Register, and the Tribe must maintain and update the roll. Future membership is determined by the Tribe, requiring lineage from a person on the base roll and ongoing political relations. SEC. 7. JURISDICTION. The reservation established by this Act will be considered Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. This Act will not affect any treaties involving tribes mentioned in the Act, nor any rights secured by those treaties.
